{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{BLP sources|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Richard Digance | image = Richard Digance at the 2010 Cropredy Festival.jpg | alt = Richard Digance at the 2010 Cropredy Festival | caption = Richard Digance at the 2010 Cropredy Festival | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1949|2|24|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Plaistow, Newham|Plaistow]], [[Essex]]<!-- Do not change to London, Plaistow was in Essex in 1949 -->, England | occupation = Comedian, folk-singer, media executive | website = [http://www.richarddigance.com www.richarddigance.com] | footnotes = }} '''Richard Digance''' (pronounced DYE-jance; born 24 February 1949) is an English [[comedian]] and [[folk music|folk singer]].
== Early life == Digance was born in [[Plaistow, Newham|Plaistow]], [[Essex]]<!-- Do not change to London, Plaistow was in Essex in 1949 --> (now part of [[east London]]). After his family moved to nearby [[East Ham]], he attended Vicarage Lane Primary School and then [[Langdon Academy|Thomas Lethaby Secondary Modern]]. After gaining two A-Level passes in English Literature and Modern British History, he moved to [[Glasgow]], where he studied [[mechanical engineering]] at [[Reid Kerr College]], [[Paisley, Renfrewshire|Paisley]],<ref name="devon">{{cite web |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/devon/hi/tv_and_radio/newsid_8604000/8604959.stm |title = Richard Digance |date = 6 April 2010 |website = BBC Devon |accessdate= 16 January 2014}}</ref> during which time he was inspired by [[Billy Connolly]] and [[Mike Harding]].<ref name="yorkshire">{{cite web |url = http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/yorkshire-living/arts/theatre/the-big-interview-richard-digance-1-5287090 |title = The Big Interview: Richard Digance |date = 7 January 2013 |website = Yorkshire Post |accessdate= 16 January 2014}}</ref>
== Career == In the 1970s he toured the United States. Though failing to make much of a name, he ended up a support act for [[Steve Martin]].<ref name="devon"/> He supported [[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]] in 87 concerts.
In 1971, he recorded an LP whilst with the group Pisces for the Trailer label.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.mustrad.org.uk/lea_txt3.htm |title = Traditional Records Discography - file 3 |website = Musical Traditions |accessdate= 16 January 2014}}</ref> It features the moorland ballad [[Jack_o'_Legs|"Jack O'Legs"]] about a 14-foot-tall highwayman.
Richard Digance began his TV career on ''[[Sound of The City]]'' for [[Thames TV]], produced by Richard Newman, in the early 1970s. This debut appearance was followed by ''[[The Old Grey Whistle Test]]'' and then the ''Today'' programme. ''The Whistle Test'' was his only BBC TV appearance except for appearing on ''The Ronnie Corbett Show'' years later and then link-man for BBC2 coverage of The [[Cambridge Folk Festival]]. He then became a regular contributor on ''The 6 o'clock Show'' with Michael Aspel. He had to wait over a decade to be given his own show.
His first own TV Special was in 1985 for Thames TV, ''A Dabble With Digance'', and featured newsreader [[Carol Barnes]]. After the success of this special he was signed to [[Television South|TVS]] in Southampton after being a studio warm-up act there for [[Matthew Kelly]] and this first series of six programmes screened on Thursday nights. He also filmed a pilot ''The Three Busketeers'' featuring himself, [[Chris Barrie]] who went on to star in ''[[Red Dwarf]]'', and [[Adrian Hedley]]. At this time he still continued as a studio warm-up act for ''[[The Des O'Connor Show]]''. He was also appearing regularly on late night shows for [[Tyne Tees Television]] with [[Gillian Reynolds]].
Richard left for London Weekend Television under [[Greg Dyke]] and filmed numerous Saturday night TV Specials for ITV. His guests included [[Status Quo]], [[Brian May]], Elkie Brooks, The Moody Blues, [[Marc Cohn]], Buffy St Marie, Joe Pasquale, Juan Martin, Julia Fordham, Chris de Burgh and many others. An additional series with [[Jim Davidson]] ''Wednesday At 8'' made him a popular guest during this period from 1985 to 1995. His guest-spots are almost endless; ''[[Surprise, Surprise (TV series)|Surprise Surprise]]'' with [[Cilla Black]] - ''The Gloria Hunniford Show'' - ''The Jim Davidson Show'' - ''Des O'Connor Show'' - ''Live From Her Majesty's'' - ''Live From Piccadilly'' - ''Summertime Special with Michael Barrymore'' - ''Live From The Palladium with Roy Orbison'' - ''[[The Comedians (1971 TV series)|The Comedians]]'' - ''[[Magpie (TV series)|Magpie]]'' - ''Celebrity Snooker'' and ''Fish o'Mania with Steve Davis'' - ''[[Pebble Mill At One]]'' - ''Saturday Night At The Mill'' - ''That's Entertainment with Kenny Everett and Julian Clary'' - ''[[Crosswits]]'' - ''The Tom O'Connor Show'' - ''The Parkinson Show with Tommy Steele'' and many more. He received a BAFTA Nomination as TV Entertainer Of The Year.
He came to public attention as a regular turn on the popular Sunday evening ''Live from... ([[Her Majesty's Theatre|Her Majesty's]]/the Piccadilly/the [[London Palladium|Palladium]])'' variety series (produced by [[LWT]] for [[ITV Network|ITV]]) and also on ''[[Summertime Special]]'', a variety showcase of the 1980s. Digance also was the support act for U.K. singer [[Elkie Brooks]] on many occasions.
He is known for his television one-hour specials, starting in 1985 with ''A Dabble of Digance''. ''Abracadigance'' was a series of four shows in 1988. The 1992 show, ''Richard Digance's Greatest Bits'', recorded at the [[Brighton|Brighton Dome]], included some of his most popular routines from stage and screen, including the "Nursery Rhymes", "Remembers" and "Jungle Cup Final".
Appearances on TV Specials included HRH The Prince of Wales Princes Trust Galas at The London Palladium with Elton John and Robin Williams - All At Sea, again before HRH The Prince of Wales - Christmas Eve Forces Special from The Berlin Wall - The Zeebrugge Disaster Concert at The London Palladium with Bernard Manning.
In the next decade he made two series for Carlton Westcountry TV visiting villages in a Morris Traveller and using locals as guests.<ref name="yorkshire"/>
Digance also had a short-lived [[BBC Radio 2]] programme titled ''[[Another Digance Indulgence]]'', which ran over eight episodes in the summer of 1987.
Many albums featuring his comic and serious music have been released. His first [[novel]], ''Run Out In The Country'', was published in 1983, and his [[autobiography]], ''A Wealth of Comedy'', in 1999.
He was a regular guest in 'Dictionary Corner' on the [[Channel 4]] game show ''[[Countdown (game show)|Countdown]]'', during which he performed comic rhymes before the commercial break.<ref name="yorkshire"/>
Digance was the [[managing director]] of Creative Results and [[Sound TV]], a [[Sky (UK and Ireland)|satellite channel]] based on [[variety show|variety]], which launched in February 2005.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/features/feature.php/7855 |publisher=The Stage |title= Rejuvenating variety with Sound TV |date=19 May 2005}}</ref> However, he resigned in August 2005, and the channel went into administration.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/10749/variety-channel-sound-tv-off-air-within-year| publisher=The Stage |title= Variety channel Sound TV off air within year of launch |date=6 December 2005}}</ref> He also co-founded SKD Media, later to become [[Entertainment Rights]]; these are involved in releasing nostalgic programming on DVD.
In October 2003 he received the Gold Award from the [[British Academy of Songwriters, Composers and Authors]] for his services to music.<ref name="devon"/><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.goldbadgeawards.com/legacy/legacy2003.htm |title = Gold Badge Awards 2003 |website = Gold Badge Awards |accessdate = 16 January 2014 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140116220356/http://www.goldbadgeawards.com/legacy/legacy2003.htm |archivedate = 16 January 2014 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
He also annually takes to the stage at [[Cropredy Festival]] for the first set on the final day.
He appeared at the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] in 2013,<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/music/richard-digance |title = Richard Digance - Edinburgh Festival Fringe |website = Edinburgh Festival Fringe |accessdate = 16 January 2014 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131020075122/https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/music/richard-digance |archivedate = 20 October 2013 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> performing a solo show, and also his children's musical, ''War of the Worms'', narrated by his daughter, Rosie. He aimed to perform 22 completely different shows across 22 nights.<ref>{{cite web |title=Interview: Richard Digance |date=2 August 2013 |url=http://www.gigglebeats.co.uk/2013/08/interview-richard-digance/ |work=Giggle Beats}}</ref>
== Personal life == Richard has two daughters, Polly and Rosie.<ref name="yorkshire" />
Former resident of Debden, Saffron Walden in Essex.
